intro: Sagina thiebautii, commonly known as the desert pearlweed, is a low-growing, mat-forming plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the family Caryophyllaceae and is characterized by its small, succulent-like leaves and clusters of tiny, white flowers. The plant thrives in sandy or rocky soils and is adapted to withstand drought and high temperatures. Its compact growth habit and ability to stabilize soil make it an important species in desert ecosystems. Sagina thiebautii is often found in disturbed or unvegetated areas, contributing to the ecological resilience of its habitat.
